inventory_metadata.purpose: AI-Powered Wiring Diagram Generation via Claude Code CLI

changelog.description: Expanded cross-references for all components; added documentation categories entries; added contributor guide; added extra example circuits; updated version and metadata.

microcontrollers.name: Arduino Uno R3

warnings: Do not exceed 20mA per I/O pin
Total current from all I/O pins should not exceed 200mA
Vin must be 7-12V; lower causes instability, higher causes overheating

solutions: Try different USB cable with data lines

microcontrollers.ai_summary: 5V Arduino microcontroller with ATmega328P, 14 digital I/O (6 PWM), 6 analog inputs. Most widely supported, beginner-friendly. Use USB-B or 7-12V barrel jack for power.

failure_modes.cause: Physical stress on USB-B connector, repeated plugging
failure_modes.prevention: Use USB hub, don't bend cable, gentle insertion
failure_modes.recovery: Often unrepairable, use ICSP for programming

failure_modes.prevention: Double-check wiring, use current limiting resistors

failure_modes.cause: Drawing too much current from 3.3V or 5V rail
failure_modes.prevention: Use external power for high-current loads
failure_modes.recovery: Replace regulator IC or use external regulated supply

breadboard_layout.orientation: USB port facing outward for easy access

example_circuits.title: Blinking an LED on Arduino Uno
example_circuits.description: A simple example that blinks an LED connected to a digital pin. It demonstrates digital output and the basic Arduino setup/loop structure.

example_circuits.title: Connecting a DHT11 Sensor to Arduino Uno
example_circuits.description: Documentation page showing how to wire the DHT11 temperature/humidity sensor to various microcontrollers, including the Arduino Uno.

microcontrollers.compatibility_notes: Compatible with most Arduino shields and 5V sensors. When interfacing 3.3 V devices (like ESP32 modules or certain sensors), use level shifters. Supports digital and analog sensors such as the DHT11, DHT22 and DS18B20.

microcontrollers.name: Arduino Mega 2560 R3

causes: Using SPI pins for other purposes
solutions: Reserve pins 50-53 for SPI devices only

causes: Using Serial1/2/3 pins for digital I/O
solutions: Use Serial.begin() for USB, Serial1/2/3.begin() for hardware UARTs

microcontrollers.ai_summary: 5V Arduino with ATmega2560, 54 digital I/O (15 PWM), 16 analog inputs, 4 hardware serial ports. Use for projects needing many pins or multiple serial devices.

power_supply_limits.notes: More GPIO but same power limits as Uno

microcontrollers.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

microcontrollers.name: ESP32 DevKit 38-Pin

do_not_use_pins.reason: Connected to internal SPI flash - WILL CRASH

strapping_pins.reason: Affect boot mode - use with caution

warnings: NOT 5V TOLERANT - use level shifter for 5V sensors
GPIO6-11 are reserved for internal flash - DO NOT USE
GPIO34/35/36/39 are input-only
ADC2 unavailable when WiFi is active

causes: GPIO0 not pulled LOW during reset
solutions: Hold BOOT button while pressing EN/RST

causes: Insufficient USB power during WiFi TX

common_issues.problem: Random crashes when using certain pins
solutions: Check strapping pin states at boot

microcontrollers.ai_summary: 3.3V dual-core WiFi+Bluetooth MCU. NOT 5V tolerant - requires level shifter for 5V sensors. Avoid GPIO6-11 (flash). Input-only: GPIO34/35/36/39. Powerful but requires attention to pin selection.

failure_modes.prevention: ALWAYS use level shifter or voltage divider for 5V signals
failure_modes.recovery: Usually permanent damage - specific GPIO may be dead

failure_modes.cause: Antenna damage, RF interference, power supply noise
failure_modes.prevention: Don't touch antenna area, use clean power supply

failure_modes.cause: Power loss during write, brownout without proper handling
failure_modes.prevention: Add 100uF cap on power, enable brownout detection

esd_rating.handling: ESD strap required, anti-static bag storage

power_supply_limits.notes: 3.3V GPIO ONLY! 5V on GPIO kills chip instantly

footprint.note: Very wide - may need two breadboards side by side

breadboard_layout.placement: straddles center gap, leaves 0 holes on each side
breadboard_layout.orientation: USB port at row 1 (top), antenna end away from wires
breadboard_layout.width_warning: Fills entire breadboard width - no adjacent holes available

microcontrollers.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

microcontrollers.name: NodeMCU ESP8266 Amica V2

safe_gpio.reason: No boot conflicts, safe for any use

boot_sensitive.D3/GPIO0: Must be HIGH at boot (pulled up internally)
boot_sensitive.D4/GPIO2: Must be HIGH at boot (built-in LED)

warnings: NOT 5V TOLERANT - 3.3V logic only
D3/D4/D8 affect boot mode - don't pull LOW at startup
GPIO6-11 reserved for flash - DO NOT USE
Only 1 ADC pin (A0) with 0-1V range (scaled to 0-3.3V on module)

common_issues.problem: Won't boot with sensor on D3/D4/D8
causes: Boot pin pulled to wrong state by sensor

microcontrollers.ai_summary: 3.3V WiFi MCU, breadboard-friendly (23mm row spacing). NOT 5V tolerant. Safe pins: D1/D2/D5/D6/D7. Avoid D3/D4/D8 for sensors (boot-sensitive). Only 1 ADC.

failure_modes.cause: ESP8266 is 3.3V only, any 5V kills pins
GPIO0, GPIO2, GPIO15 pulled wrong during boot
failure_modes.prevention: Don't use D3, D4, D8 for sensors that pull low at startup

esd_rating.handling: ESD strap required, anti-static bag storage

power_supply_limits.notes: 3.3V GPIO ONLY! Very limited pins available

breadboard_layout.placement: straddles center gap, may need offset placement
breadboard_layout.orientation: USB port at row 1, antenna opposite end
breadboard_layout.width_warning: Very wide - leaves 0 holes on each side

microcontrollers.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

microcontrollers.name: SparkFun Blynk Board
microcontrollers.ai_summary: ESP8266 board with pre-loaded Blynk firmware, onboard WS2812 RGB LED on GPIO4, and 10K thermistor on ADC. Quick IoT prototyping.

esd_rating.handling: ESD strap required, anti-static bag storage

microcontrollers.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

microcontrollers.name: DCCduino Nano

warnings: Requires CH340G driver installation

solutions: Install CH340G driver from WCH website

microcontrollers.ai_summary: Arduino Nano clone with CH340G USB chip. Requires CH340 driver. 5V logic, breadboard-friendly form factor.

power_supply_limits.notes: Clone - may have weaker voltage regulator

breadboard_layout.placement: straddles center gap, pins in rows D and G

microcontrollers.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Sensor

esp32.note: ESP32 is 3.3V - Echo outputs 5V, needs divider!

esp8266.note: NodeMCU is 3.3V - use 1K+2K voltage divider on Echo

warnings: Echo pin outputs 5V - use voltage divider for 3.3V MCUs
Minimum 60ms between measurements to avoid echo interference
10μs minimum trigger pulse required

solutions: Use hard flat surfaces for testing
Add voltage divider: 1K + 2K resistors on Echo line

sensors.ai_summary: 5V ultrasonic distance sensor, 2-400cm range. Requires 2 digital pins (Trig output, Echo input). Use voltage divider on Echo for 3.3V MCUs. Min 60ms between readings.

procedure: Place sensor facing flat wall at exactly 10cm
Run test sketch, record raw reading
Move to 50cm, record reading
Move to 100cm, record reading
Calculate correction factor if readings deviate >5%

testing.quick_test: Wave hand in front, check serial output changes

failure_modes.cause: Physical damage to ultrasonic elements, water damage
failure_modes.prevention: Keep dry, don't drop, no pressure on transducers
ALWAYS use voltage divider (1K + 2K) for 3.3V MCUs
failure_modes.recovery: MCU pin likely dead, use different pin with divider

power_consumption.notes: Requires 5V, Echo pin outputs 5V (level shift for 3.3V MCU)

breadboard_layout.placement: insert in any 4 adjacent holes in same row
breadboard_layout.mounting_tip: Can use female headers for easy removal

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: HC-SR501 PIR Motion Sensor

warnings: Allow 60 seconds warmup after power-on
2.5 second lockout after output goes LOW
Avoid mounting near heat sources or AC vents

sensors.ai_summary: PIR motion sensor, 3-7m adjustable range, 110° cone. Output is 3.3V (safe for all MCUs). Requires 60s warmup. Use interrupt pin for responsive detection.

procedure: Allow 60-second warmup after power on
Adjust TIME pot: CW = longer trigger duration (5s-5min)
Adjust SENS pot: CW = longer detection range (3-7m)
Set jumper: H = repeatable trigger, L = single trigger
Walk through detection zone to verify coverage

testing.quick_test: Walk past sensor, verify output goes HIGH
testing.full_test: Map detection zone at different heights

power_consumption.notes: Very low power, wide voltage range

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: DHT11 Temperature & Humidity Module

warnings: Minimum 1 second between readings (1Hz max)
Use 3.3V power for 3.3V MCUs
Pull-up resistor required if not on module

common_issues.problem: Always returns NaN or checksum errors

solutions: Read no more than once per 2 seconds

libraries.basic_code: DHT dht(DHTPIN, DHT11); dht.begin(); float t = dht.readTemperature();

sensors.ai_summary: Temperature (0-50°C ±2°C) and humidity (20-90% ±5%) sensor. Single-wire protocol (NOT I2C). Max 1 reading per second. Use DHT library.

procedure: Compare reading against known accurate thermometer
Note offset for software correction if needed
Humidity harder to verify - use salt test or reference meter

testing.quick_test: Breathe on sensor, humidity should spike to 80%+
testing.full_test: Compare against reference for 10 readings over 1 hour

failure_modes.cause: Exposure to contaminants, very high humidity for extended time
failure_modes.prevention: Don't expose to condensation, use in controlled environment

failure_modes.cause: Missing pull-up, too long wires, reading too fast
failure_modes.prevention: Add 10K pull-up, keep wires <1m, wait 2s between reads
failure_modes.recovery: Check wiring, add pull-up if missing

power_consumption.notes: Works on 3.3V or 5V, data pin is 3.3V safe

breadboard_layout.note: Some modules have 4 pins with NC in middle

application_notes.title: How to Use DHT11: Examples, Pinouts, and Specs
DHT11 vs DHT22 vs DS18B20 Comparison

example_circuits.title: Connecting DHT11 to Arduino Uno
example_circuits.description: Typical circuit diagrams show the DHT11 connected to microcontrollers like the Arduino Uno, ESP8266 and ESP32. The data pin connects to a digital input and a pull‑up resistor is used between the data line and VCC.

example_circuits.title: ESP32 with DHT11 Web Server
example_circuits.description: Example project demonstrating how to build a web server that displays temperature and humidity readings from a DHT11 sensor using an ESP32 board.

sensors.compatibility_notes: Works with 3.3 V and 5 V logic levels and is compatible with microcontrollers like Arduino Uno, ESP8266 and ESP32【164782750892533†L110-L123】. Due to its one‑wire protocol, a 4.7 kΩ to 10 kΩ pull‑up resistor is required on the data line. Not recommended for high‑precision or high‑speed applications.

sensors.name: GY-521 MPU6050 6-DOF IMU

warnings: Module has onboard 3.3V regulator - safe for 5V VCC
I2C lines are 3.3V - use level shifter if MCU needs 5V I2C
AD0 pin selects address: GND=0x68, VCC=0x69

libraries.arduino: MPU6050 by Electronic Cats or I2Cdevlib

sensors.ai_summary: 6-axis IMU (3-axis accel + 3-axis gyro) on I2C bus. Address 0x68 (AD0=GND) or 0x69 (AD0=HIGH). Has onboard DMP for sensor fusion. Use I2C scanner to verify connection.

procedure: Place sensor on perfectly flat, level surface
Run calibration sketch (averages 1000+ readings)
Record X, Y, Z offsets for accelerometer
Record X, Y, Z offsets for gyroscope
Store offsets in EEPROM or code constants
Verify: accel should read (0, 0, 16384) when flat
Verify: gyro should read (0, 0, 0) when stationary
calibration.notes: Offsets can be written to MPU6050 offset registers for hardware correction

testing.quick_test: Tilt sensor, watch accel values change smoothly
testing.full_test: Rotate 90° on each axis, verify readings

breadboard_layout.orientation: chip markings readable, XDA/XCL pins if using aux I2C
breadboard_layout.i2c_note: Only need VCC, GND, SCL, SDA for basic use

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: DS3231 RTC Module

warnings: RTC address 0x68 conflicts with MPU6050 default - change MPU AD0 if using both
Install CR2032 battery for backup
Some modules charge the battery - use non-rechargeable CR2032 or remove charging diode

solutions: Install fresh CR2032 with + facing up
Change MPU6050 to 0x69 by connecting AD0 to VCC

libraries.basic_code: RTC_DS3231 rtc; rtc.begin(); DateTime now = rtc.now();

sensors.ai_summary: Precision RTC (±2ppm) with I2C at 0x68. Includes 4KB EEPROM at 0x57 and CR2032 backup. NOTE: Same I2C address as MPU6050 - change MPU AD0 if using both.

procedure: Set time from accurate source (NTP or atomic clock reference)
Use rtc.adjust(DateTime(F(__DATE__), F(__TIME__))) for compile-time sync
Or set manually with exact time
Verify after 24 hours - should be within ±2 seconds

breadboard_layout.i2c_note: Only need VCC, GND, SCL, SDA for timekeeping

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: RC522 RFID Module

arduino_uno.note: Module is 3.3V but most clones work with 5V Arduino SPI

warnings: VCC is 3.3V ONLY - 5V will damage the module
SPI pins are 3.3V tolerant
Antenna coil is fragile - don't bend PCB

sensors.ai_summary: 13.56MHz RFID reader on SPI bus. 3.3V ONLY - will be damaged by 5V! Includes card and keychain fob. Use MFRC522 library.

procedure: Test read distance with known MIFARE card
Typical range is 2-5cm depending on card/antenna

breadboard_layout.spi_note: SDA on this module is SS/CS, not I2C

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: KY-023 Joystick Module

esp32.note: Use 3.3V for ESP32 - output will be 0-4095 (12-bit)

solutions: Calibrate in software - read center position at startup

sensors.ai_summary: Dual-axis analog joystick with center button. Uses 2 analog pins + 1 digital. Center position ~512 on Arduino. Button is active LOW.

procedure: Read X and Y with stick centered → record CENTER_X, CENTER_Y
Typical center is ~512, but varies 480-540
Define dead zone (±20-50 from center)
Map to -100 to +100 range with dead zone

testing.quick_test: Move stick to corners, verify full range
testing.full_test: Test button press, verify all axes

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: KY-040 Rotary Encoder
sensors.ai_summary: 20-detent rotary encoder with quadrature output and push button. Use interrupt pins for CLK/DT for reliable counting.
sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: Photoresistor (LDR)
sensors.ai_summary: Light sensor using voltage divider. Higher light = lower resistance = higher analog reading. Use 10K resistor to GND.

procedure: Cover sensor completely → record as DARK_VALUE
Expose to bright light (flashlight) → record as BRIGHT_VALUE
Map readings to lux or percentage as needed

testing.quick_test: Cover with hand, verify reading increases
testing.full_test: Compare against phone lux meter at 3 light levels

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: Soil Moisture Sensor

warnings: Probes corrode quickly in wet soil - don't leave powered constantly

sensors.ai_summary: Capacitive soil sensor. A0 gives analog reading (lower = wetter). Power only when reading to extend probe life.

procedure: Read value in completely dry air → record as DRY_VALUE
Submerge probe in water → record as WET_VALUE
Map readings: moisture% = map(reading, DRY, WET, 0, 100)

testing.quick_test: Touch probe to wet finger, reading should drop
testing.full_test: Test in actual soil at known moisture levels

power_consumption.notes: High current draw - consider intermittent readings

sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: Flame Sensor Module
sensors.ai_summary: IR flame sensor. Detects 760-1100nm wavelength (fire). D0 for threshold detection, A0 for intensity.
sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: Water Level Sensor
sensors.ai_summary: Conductive water level sensor. Analog output proportional to water height. Power intermittently to reduce electrolysis.
sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: KY-038 Sound Sensor
sensors.ai_summary: Sound detection module. A0 for analog level, D0 for threshold detection (clap sensor). Adjust sensitivity with pot.
sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: IR Obstacle Avoidance Sensor
sensors.ai_summary: IR proximity sensor. Output LOW when obstacle in range. Adjust range with pot. Works 2-30cm typical.
sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

sensors.name: SW-520D Tilt Switch

wiring_rules.connection: Acts as SPST switch - use with pull-up resistor

sensors.ai_summary: Ball-type tilt switch. Closes circuit when tilted past threshold. Use INPUT_PULLUP, reads LOW when tilted.
sensors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

actuators.name: SG90 Micro Servo

warnings: Stall current can exceed 500mA - use external power for multiple servos
Never power from MCU 5V pin if using more than 1 servo
Common GND between servo power supply and MCU required

common_issues.problem: Servo jitters or doesn't hold position

causes: Servo drawing too much current from Arduino 5V
solutions: Power servo from external 5V supply, share GND with Arduino

actuators.ai_summary: 180° micro servo, 9g. PWM control: 1ms=0°, 1.5ms=90°, 2ms=180°. Use external 5V supply for multiple servos. Brown=GND, Red=VCC, Orange=Signal.

procedure: Send 90° command, physically verify middle position
Send 0° command, verify left limit
Send 180° command, verify right limit
Adjust min/max pulse widths if range is off

failure_modes.cause: Forcing past mechanical stop, dropping, overload
failure_modes.prevention: Don't command beyond 0-180°, don't force shaft
failure_modes.recovery: Replace servo (gears are usually not replaceable)

failure_modes.cause: Stalling against load, continuous operation at high load
Age, continuous movement in same range

power_consumption.notes: DO NOT power from MCU pin! Use external 5V for >1 servo

breadboard_layout.placement: connect via male header pins or jumper wires
breadboard_layout.mounting_tip: Use 3-pin male header strip to plug into breadboard

actuators.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

actuators.name: 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motor with ULN2003 Driver

warnings: Motor draws ~240mA - use external power supply
Driver LEDs show which coil is active
Gear train makes motor slow but high torque

solutions: Use Stepper library with correct pin order
Disable motor when not moving (call stepper.release())

libraries.basic_code: Stepper myStepper(2048, IN1, IN3, IN2, IN4); myStepper.setSpeed(10); myStepper.step(2048);

actuators.ai_summary: 5V geared stepper, 4096 steps/rev, ~15 RPM max. Requires 4 digital pins + ULN2003 driver. Use external 5V power. AccelStepper library for smooth motion.

procedure: Mark starting position
Command 2048 steps (1 revolution)
Verify shaft returned to mark
If not exact, adjust steps_per_revolution constant

testing.full_test: 10 full revolutions, verify no missed steps

power_consumption.notes: 240mA per motor - ALWAYS use external power

breadboard_layout.placement: beside breadboard, connect via jumper wires

connections.control_pins: IN1, IN2, IN3, IN4 to MCU GPIO

actuators.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

actuators.name: L293D Motor Driver IC

warnings: Chip gets HOT - heatsink recommended above 400mA
Ground pins (4,5,12,13) also act as heatsink - solder to large copper area
Internal diodes protect against back-EMF but add voltage drop

solutions: Add heatsink or copper pour under chip

common_issues.problem: Motor doesn't run in both directions
solutions: Connect enable pins to 5V or PWM pin

actuators.ai_summary: Dual H-bridge motor driver IC. 600mA/channel. Pin 16=5V logic, Pin 8=motor voltage (4.5-36V). Enable pins control on/off or PWM speed. Gets hot - add heatsink.

breadboard_layout.heatsink_note: Center pins (4,5,12,13) are ground/heatsink - connect all to GND

actuators.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

actuators.name: 5V Relay Module

load_side.no: Normally Open - connects to COM when relay energized
load_side.nc: Normally Closed - connects to COM when relay off

warnings: DANGER: Load side can carry mains voltage - use extreme caution
Keep high voltage wiring away from low voltage Arduino circuits
Active LOW: digitalWrite(pin, LOW) turns relay ON
Relay coil draws ~70mA - within Arduino pin limit but use transistor for multiple relays

common_issues.problem: Relay clicks but doesn't switch load
solutions: Wire load between COM and NO or NC as needed
Module has built-in protection but add 100uF cap on Arduino 5V

actuators.ai_summary: 5V relay module with optocoupler isolation. Active LOW trigger. Load terminals: COM (common), NO (normally open), NC (normally closed). CAUTION: Can switch mains voltage.

power_consumption.notes: Coil draws 70mA - close to single pin limit

actuators.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

displays.name: LCD 1602 Module

warnings: Contrast (V0) must be adjusted - display may appear blank without it
Use 10K potentiometer between VDD and VSS, wiper to V0
I2C backpack reduces wiring from 12+ pins to 4 pins

common_issues.problem: Display shows boxes or is blank
solutions: Adjust V0 potentiometer until text visible

displays.ai_summary: 16x2 character LCD. Parallel mode needs 6+ pins; I2C backpack needs only 2 (SDA/SCL). MUST adjust contrast pot (V0) or display appears blank.

power_consumption.notes: Most current is backlight - can PWM dim

breadboard_layout.breadboard_compatible: I2C version yes, parallel version no
breadboard_layout.mounting: I2C backpack recommended for fewer wires

displays.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

displays.name: MAX7219 8x8 LED Matrix Module

wiring_rules.cascading: Connect DOUT of first module to DIN of second

libraries.basic_code: LedControl lc(DIN, CLK, CS, 1); lc.setLed(0, row, col, true);

displays.ai_summary: 8x8 LED matrix with MAX7219 driver. SPI interface, cascadable for larger displays. 5V operation, 16 brightness levels.
displays.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

logic_interface.name: HW-221 Logic Level Converter
logic_interface.ai_summary: 4-channel bidirectional level shifter. Connect LV to 3.3V reference, HV to 5V reference, share GND. Works for I2C, SPI, UART up to ~400kHz.
logic_interface.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

logic_interface.name: 74HC595 Shift Register

libraries.basic_code: shiftOut(dataPin, clockPin, MSBFIRST, data); digitalWrite(latchPin, HIGH);

logic_interface.ai_summary: 8-bit serial-to-parallel shift register. Expands 3 pins to 8 outputs. Cascadable for more outputs. Use shiftOut() function.
logic_interface.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

power_prototyping.name: MB102 Breadboard Power Supply

wiring_rules.input: DC barrel jack 6.5-12V OR USB (not both)
wiring_rules.output: Plugs directly into breadboard power rails
wiring_rules.jumpers: Set each rail independently to 3.3V or 5V
warnings: Do not use barrel jack and USB simultaneously
Max 700mA total - don't overload

power_prototyping.ai_summary: Breadboard power module with independent 3.3V/5V rails. Input: 6.5-12V barrel jack or USB. Max 700mA total. Use jumpers to select voltage per rail.
power_prototyping.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

power_prototyping.name: 830-Point Solderless Breadboard
power_prototyping.ai_summary: Standard 830-point breadboard. Center channel for DIP ICs. 4 power rails (2 per side). Check rail continuity - some boards have breaks in the middle.
power_prototyping.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

power_prototyping.name: 400-Point Mini Breadboard
power_prototyping.ai_summary: Half-size 400-point breadboard. Good for small circuits or mounting on project bases.
power_prototyping.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

power_prototyping.name: Jumper Wire Assortment
power_prototyping.ai_summary: Jumper wire kit with M-M, M-F, and F-F connectors. M-M for breadboard, M-F for Arduino headers to breadboard, F-F for sensor modules.
power_prototyping.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

power_prototyping.name: 9V Battery Barrel Jack Adapter
power_prototyping.ai_summary: 9V battery clip with 2.1mm barrel plug. Center positive - compatible with Arduino barrel jack. ~500mAh capacity typical.
power_prototyping.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

shields.name: L293D Motor Shield

wiring_rules.stacking: Plugs directly onto Arduino Uno headers
wiring_rules.power_jumper: Remove to use separate motor power supply

shields.ai_summary: Arduino motor shield with 2x L293D. Drives 4 DC motors OR 2 steppers + 2 servos. Uses pins 3-12. Use external power for motors >6V.
shields.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

shields.name: CNC Shield V3 (GRBL)
shields.ai_summary: GRBL CNC shield for 3-4 axis control. Accepts A4988/DRV8825 drivers. Use with GRBL firmware for G-code control.
shields.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

shields.name: Arduino Prototyping Shield
shields.ai_summary: Proto shield with small breadboard area for custom circuits. Good for making permanent Arduino add-ons.
shields.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

shields.name: Screw Terminal Shield
shields.ai_summary: Breaks out all Arduino Uno pins to screw terminals for secure, solderless connections.
shields.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

shields.name: 2.8" TFT LCD Shield (ILI9341)
shields.ai_summary: 2.8" 240x320 color TFT with ILI9341 controller. SPI interface. Use Adafruit_GFX + Adafruit_ILI9341 libraries. Optional touch + SD card.
shields.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

audio.name: Piezo Buzzer

wiring_rules.connection: One pin to digital output (PWM), other to GND

audio.ai_summary: Passive piezo buzzer. Use tone(pin, frequency) to play sounds. Loudest at resonant frequency (~2.4kHz).
audio.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

audio.name: 8Ω Mini Speaker

wiring_rules.direct: Through transistor amplifier (TIP120) or audio amp module
wiring_rules.warning: Do NOT connect directly to Arduino pins - will damage pin

audio.ai_summary: 8Ω 0.5W speaker. Requires amplifier - do NOT connect directly to MCU pins. Use PAM8403 module or transistor driver.
audio.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

discrete_semiconductors.name: TIP120 Darlington Transistor
discrete_semiconductors.ai_summary: NPN Darlington, 5A/60V. High gain (1000) - can drive from MCU pin via 1K resistor. ALWAYS use flyback diode with motors/solenoids.
discrete_semiconductors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

discrete_semiconductors.name: 2N2222 NPN Transistor
discrete_semiconductors.ai_summary: General purpose NPN transistor. TO-92 pinout: E-B-C (flat side facing you). Good for switching up to 800mA loads.
discrete_semiconductors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

discrete_semiconductors.name: IRF520 MOSFET Module

warnings: Not fully ON at 3.3V gate - use 5V MCU or logic level MOSFET
Module handles gate drive, not bare MOSFET

discrete_semiconductors.ai_summary: MOSFET module for PWM control of high-current loads. Works with 5V logic. Use for LED strips, motors up to 9A. Not ideal for 3.3V MCUs.
discrete_semiconductors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

capacitors.name: Electrolytic Capacitor Assortment
capacitors.ai_summary: Electrolytic caps 1-470uF. POLARIZED - long leg is positive. Common uses: 100uF on power rails, 10uF on sensor modules.
capacitors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

capacitors.name: Ceramic Capacitor Assortment
capacitors.ai_summary: Ceramic caps. Non-polarized. 100nF (104) most useful - place near every IC VCC pin for decoupling.
capacitors.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

leds.name: 5mm LED Assortment

wiring_rules.polarity: Long leg = Anode (+), Short leg / Flat side = Cathode (-)

leds.ai_summary: 5mm LEDs. Long leg = positive. Use resistor: 150Ω for red/yellow/green at 5V, 68Ω for blue/white at 5V.

breadboard_layout.placement: two adjacent holes, can span gap

polarity.anode_long_leg: positive, connect to resistor then VCC

leds.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

leds.name: WS2812B Addressable LED Strip

common_issues.problem: First LED wrong color or flickering

leds.ai_summary: 60 LEDs/m addressable RGB strip. 5V power (60mA per LED = 3.6A for 60 LEDs!). Use FastLED library. Add 1000uF cap + 470Ω data resistor.

symptoms: First LED stays off or random color
failure_modes.cause: Voltage spike at power-on, no resistor on data line
failure_modes.prevention: Add 1000uF cap on power, 300-500Ω resistor on data
failure_modes.recovery: Cut off first LED, reattach to second LED

failure_modes.prevention: Don't exceed 50% brightness continuously, adequate cooling

failure_modes.mode: Voltage drop - end LEDs dim/wrong color
symptoms: Colors shift to red at end
failure_modes.cause: Voltage drop over length - 5V at start, 3.5V at end

DOUT.function: data to next LED in chain

leds.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

leds.name: RGB LED (Common Cathode)

wiring_rules.resistors: Use separate resistor for each color (150Ω typical at 5V)
wiring_rules.connection: Cathode to GND, anodes to PWM pins via resistors

leds.ai_summary: 4-pin RGB LED. Longest leg = common cathode (GND). Use PWM on each color pin for mixing. analogWrite(pin, 0-255) for each color.
leds.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

bulk_passives.name: Resistor Assortment Kit
bulk_passives.ai_summary: 1/4W resistor kit. Most used: 220Ω (LEDs), 1K-10K (pull-ups, base resistors), 4.7K (I2C). Use color code calculator if unsure.

breadboard_layout.placement: bend leads, insert in two holes same row or across gap

bulk_passives.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

bulk_passives.name: 10K Potentiometer
bulk_passives.ai_summary: 10K linear pot. As voltage divider: outer pins to GND/VCC, wiper to analog pin. Reads 0-1023 on Arduino.
bulk_passives.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

bulk_passives.name: Tactile Pushbutton Assortment
bulk_passives.ai_summary: Tactile buttons. Use INPUT_PULLUP mode, connect other side to GND. Button pressed = LOW. Add debounce (10-50ms delay).
bulk_passives.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

bulk_passives.name: Header Pin Assortment
bulk_passives.ai_summary: 2.54mm pitch headers. Break to length needed. Male for breadboard insertion, female for module sockets.
bulk_passives.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: Dupont Jumper Wires
accessories.ai_summary: Dupont jumper kit. M-M for breadboard, M-F for Arduino headers to breadboard, F-F for connecting modules with male headers.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: USB Cable Set
accessories.ai_summary: USB cables for programming. USB-B for Uno/Mega, Mini-USB for Nano, Micro-USB for ESP boards.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: DC Barrel Jack Connectors
accessories.ai_summary: 2.1mm barrel jacks for Arduino-compatible power. Center positive standard.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: Heat Shrink Tubing Assortment
accessories.ai_summary: Heat shrink tubing kit. Use heat gun or lighter to shrink. Insulates solder joints and wire splices.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: M3 Standoff/Spacer Kit
accessories.ai_summary: M3 standoff kit for mounting Arduino/PCBs. Standard Arduino hole spacing uses M3.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: Header Pin Assortment
accessories.ai_summary: 2.54mm header pins. Break to length. Male for breadboard insertion, female for socket connections.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: Prototype PCB Assortment
accessories.ai_summary: Perfboard PCBs for permanent projects. 2.54mm pitch matches headers and DIP ICs.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: PCB Screw Terminal Blocks
accessories.ai_summary: Screw terminals for power and motor connections. Solder to PCB, accept bare wire.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: Alligator Clip Test Leads
accessories.ai_summary: Alligator clip leads for temporary connections and testing. Don't use for permanent wiring.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

accessories.name: Multimeter Test Probes
accessories.ai_summary: Replacement/upgrade multimeter probes with interchangeable tips.
accessories.compatibility_notes: Consult datasheet for voltage, current, and pin compatibility with your project.

robot_obstacle_avoider.name: Robot Obstacle Avoider
robot_obstacle_avoider.description: Simple robot that detects and avoids obstacles

weather_station.name: WiFi Weather Station
weather_station.description: IoT weather monitor with web dashboard

smart_plant_monitor.name: Smart Plant Watering System
smart_plant_monitor.description: Automated plant watering based on soil moisture

game_controller.name: USB Game Controller
game_controller.description: Custom game controller with joystick and buttons

data_logger.name: Environmental Data Logger
data_logger.description: SD card data logger with timestamp

i2c_address_conflicts.resolution: Change MPU6050 AD0 to HIGH for 0x69

mutually_exclusive_pins.conflict: SPI uses pins 10-13, can't use for other digital I/O during SPI
GPIO1,3 used for Serial, GPIO6-11 for flash

ascii_pinouts.esp32_devkit_38:
┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐
│              ESP32 DevKit 38-Pin          │
│     ┌─────────────────────────────┐       │
│     │         ESP-WROOM-32        │       │
│     │      ┌─────────────┐        │       │
│     │      │   Antenna   │        │       │
│     └──────┴─────────────┴────────┘       │
│                                           │
│ LEFT SIDE              RIGHT SIDE         │
│ ┌────┬─────┐          ┌─────┬────┐        │
│ │3V3 │ 3.3V│          │ GND │ GND│        │
│ │EN  │Reset│          │IO23 │MOSI│        │
│ │VP  │ IO36│◄IN ONLY  │IO22 │ SCL│        │
│ │VN  │ IO39│◄IN ONLY  │TX0  │ IO1│        │
│ │IO34│◄────│IN ONLY   │RX0  │ IO3│        │
│ │IO35│◄────│IN ONLY   │IO21 │ SDA│        │
│ │IO32│     │          │GND  │ GND│        │
│ │IO33│     │          │IO19 │MISO│        │
│ │IO25│ DAC1│          │IO18 │ SCK│        │
│ │IO26│ DAC2│          │IO5  │ SS │ ⚠BOOT  │
│ │IO27│     │          │IO17 │    │        │
│ │IO14│     │          │IO16 │    │        │
│ │IO12│     │ ⚠BOOT    │IO4  │    │        │
│ │GND │ GND │          │IO0  │    │ ⚠BOOT  │
│ │IO13│     │          │IO2  │    │ ⚠BOOT  │
│ │D2  │FLASH│◄NO USE   │IO15 │    │ ⚠BOOT  │
│ │D3  │FLASH│◄NO USE   │D1   │FLASH◄NO USE│
│ │CMD │FLASH│◄NO USE   │D0   │FLASH◄NO USE│
│ │5V  │ VIN │          │CLK  │FLASH◄NO USE│
│ └────┴─────┘          └─────┴────┘        │
│                                           │
│ ⚠ = Strapping pin (affects boot mode)    │
│ ◄IN ONLY = Input only, no pull-up        │
│ ◄NO USE = Internal flash, DO NOT USE     │
└───────────────────────────────────────────┘
ascii_pinouts.74hc595:
┌───────────────────────────────┐
│      74HC595 Shift Register   │
│                               │
│      ┌─────┬─U─┬─────┐        │
│  QB ─┤1         16├─ VCC      │
│  QC ─┤2         15├─ QA       │
│  QD ─┤3         14├─ DS (SER) │
│  QE ─┤4   595   13├─ OE       │
│  QF ─┤5         12├─ STCP     │
│  QG ─┤6         11├─ SHCP     │
│  QH ─┤7         10├─ MR       │
│ GND ─┤8          9├─ QH'      │
│      └───────────┘            │
│                               │
│ Pin 14 (DS/SER)  = Data In    │
│ Pin 11 (SHCP)    = Shift Clock│
│ Pin 12 (STCP)    = Latch Clock│
│ Pin 13 (OE)      = Output En  │
│ Pin 10 (MR)      = Master Rst │
│ Pin 9  (QH')     = Serial Out │
│ Pins 1-7,15      = Outputs    │
│                               │
│ Typical: OE→GND, MR→VCC       │
└───────────────────────────────┘

arduino_uno_blink.description: Basic LED blink - verify board works

schema_definition.description: JSON Schema for Electronics Inventory optimized for AI wiring diagram generation

operating_voltage_v.note: number for single, object for range {min, max}

signals.description: Pin name to signal type mapping

category_definitions.sensors: Input devices that measure physical quantities
category_definitions.actuators: Output devices that create motion or force
category_definitions.displays: Visual output devices (LCD, LED matrix, TFT)

input.description: Devices that sense or receive data

output.description: Devices that produce action or display

spec_confidence_definitions.datasheet: From manufacturer datasheet, not personally verified
spec_confidence_definitions.typical: Common values, may vary by specific unit/manufacturer
spec_confidence_definitions.estimated: Inferred from similar components or partial info

storage_template.description: Template for tracking physical storage locations

shelf_life.description: Expected storage life (e.g., 'indefinite', '5 years', '2 years if sealed')

recommended_by_esd_class.Class_1A: anti-static bag, desiccant, ESD mat for work
recommended_by_esd_class.Class_1C: standard parts bin or anti-static bag

reserved_pins.0: Serial RX - avoid if using Serial Monitor
reserved_pins.1: Serial TX - avoid if using Serial Monitor
reserved_pins.10: SPI SS - avoid if using SPI
reserved_pins.11: SPI MOSI - avoid if using SPI
reserved_pins.12: SPI MISO - avoid if using SPI
reserved_pins.13: SPI SCK + LED - avoid for input sensors
reserved_pins.A4: I2C SDA - avoid if using I2C
reserved_pins.A5: I2C SCL - avoid if using I2C

best_practices: Use pins 2-9 for general purpose I/O
Use PWM pins (3,5,6,9,10,11) for motor/LED control
A4,A5 are shared with I2C - can't use analog if I2C active
Plenty of pins - use 22-49 for general I/O
Analog pins A0-A15 don't conflict with I2C

esp32_devkit_38pin.pwm_pins: all GPIO can do PWM via LEDC

strapping_pins.0: Boot mode - must be HIGH for normal boot, LOW for download
strapping_pins.2: Boot mode - must be LOW for download mode
strapping_pins.12: Flash voltage - leave floating or LOW

critical_warnings: ALL GPIO ARE 3.3V ONLY - 5V DESTROYS THE CHIP
ADC2 cannot be used while WiFi is active
GPIO 6-11 are connected to flash - NEVER USE
best_practices: Avoid strapping pins for critical boot-time signals
Add level shifter for ANY 5V component

boot_sensitive_pins.GPIO0: D3 - Must be HIGH for normal boot
boot_sensitive_pins.GPIO2: D4 - Must be HIGH for normal boot
boot_sensitive_pins.GPIO15: D8 - Must be LOW for normal boot

critical_warnings: ALL GPIO ARE 3.3V ONLY - 5V DESTROYS THE CHIP
D3, D4, D8 affect boot - avoid sensors that pull at startup
ADC limited to 0-1V (use voltage divider for higher)
best_practices: Use D1, D2, D5, D6, D7 for most projects
D0 can't do PWM and has special wake function
Don't connect anything to D3, D4, D8 that pulls during boot
Use D-pin labels in code (D1, D2...) not GPIO numbers

power_budget_calculator.description: Rules for calculating total power consumption
power_budget_calculator.formula: total_ma = mcu_ma + sum(component_active_ma for each component)

rules.name: usb_power_check
rules.message: Total current ({total_ma}mA) exceeds USB limit (500mA)
rules.solution: Use external power supply or reduce load

rules.name: gpio_pin_overload
rules.message: Component draws {component_ma}mA but GPIO max is {mcu_per_pin_ma}mA
rules.solution: Use transistor/MOSFET to switch load, or external power

rules.name: total_gpio_overload
rules.message: Total GPIO load ({sum}mA) exceeds MCU limit ({limit}mA)
rules.solution: Use external power for high-current devices

rules.name: servo_power_warning
rules.message: Servos should use external 5V power
rules.solution: Connect servo VCC to external 5V, share GND with MCU

rules.name: ws2812b_power_calculation
rules.message: {led_count} WS2812B LEDs need {power_ma}mA at full white
rules.solution: Use adequate external power supply (5V {amps}A minimum)

wiring_validation_rules.description: Machine-readable rules for validating wiring diagrams

rules.name: voltage_level_mismatch
rules.message: Voltage mismatch: {mcu} is {mcu_voltage}V logic but {component} requires {comp_voltage}V
rules.solution: Add level shifter between MCU and component
examples: ESP32 (3.3V) → HC-SR04 Echo (5V output) = DAMAGE RISK

rules.name: 5v_to_3v3_gpio
rules.message: 5V signal {component}.{pin} will DESTROY 3.3V GPIO on {mcu}
rules.solution: Use voltage divider (1KΩ + 2KΩ) or level shifter

rules.name: gpio_current_exceeded
rules.message: {component} draws {current}mA but {mcu} GPIO max is {limit}mA
rules.solution: Use transistor (TIP120/2N2222) or MOSFET (IRF520) to switch load

rules.name: total_current_exceeded
rules.message: Total current {total}mA exceeds USB power limit 500mA
rules.solution: Use external power supply, connect GND to MCU

rules.name: servo_direct_power
rules.message: Servo powered from MCU can cause brownout/reset
rules.solution: Use external 5V supply for servo VCC, share GND with MCU

rules.name: stepper_direct_power
rules.message: Stepper motors MUST use external power (240mA+ each)
rules.solution: Connect ULN2003 VCC to external 5V, share GND

rules.name: i2c_address_conflict
rules.message: I2C address conflict: {components} both use address {address}
rules.solution: Change address via hardware pin (if available) or use I2C multiplexer

rules.name: spi_ss_conflict
rules.message: Multiple SPI devices need unique SS/CS pins
rules.solution: Assign different GPIO to each device SS pin

rules.name: esp32_flash_pins
rules.message: GPIO {pin} is connected to flash memory - NEVER USE

rules.name: esp8266_boot_pins

condition.check: mcu == 'ESP8266' AND pin in ['GPIO0','GPIO2','GPIO15'] AND component.pulls_at_boot

rules.message: {pin} affects boot - {component} may prevent boot
rules.solution: Move sensor to safe pin (D1, D2, D5, D6, D7)

rules.name: pwm_required

condition.check: component.requires_pwm AND pin not in mcu.pwm_pins

rules.message: {component} needs PWM but pin {pin} is not PWM capable
rules.solution: Move to PWM pin: {pwm_pins}

rules.name: interrupt_required

condition.check: component.requires_interrupt AND pin not in mcu.interrupt_pins

rules.message: {component} works best with interrupt but pin {pin} is not interrupt capable
rules.solution: For better performance, use interrupt pin: {interrupt_pins}

rules.name: analog_required

condition.check: component.output_type == 'analog' AND pin not in mcu.analog_pins

rules.message: {component} outputs analog signal but pin {pin} cannot read analog
rules.solution: Connect to analog pin: {analog_pins}

rules.name: pullup_required
rules.message: {component} data line needs pull-up resistor
rules.solution: Add 4.7KΩ-10KΩ resistor from data pin to VCC

rules.name: flyback_diode_required
rules.message: Inductive load {component} needs flyback diode for protection
rules.solution: Add 1N4007 diode across coil (cathode to positive)

rules.name: led_resistor_required
rules.message: LED needs current limiting resistor or will burn out
rules.solution: Add 220Ω-330Ω resistor in series with LED

rules.name: ws2812b_data_resistor
rules.message: WS2812B data line should have series resistor
rules.solution: Add 300-500Ω resistor on data line near MCU

rules.name: ws2812b_capacitor
rules.message: WS2812B power should have bulk capacitor
rules.solution: Add 1000µF capacitor across power rails near LEDs

rules.name: esp_adc2_wifi_conflict

condition.check: mcu == 'ESP32' AND wifi_enabled AND analog_pin in adc2_pins

rules.message: ADC2 pins cannot be used while WiFi is active
rules.solution: Use ADC1 pins (32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 39) for analog when using WiFi

rules.name: input_only_pin_output

condition.check: mcu == 'ESP32' AND pin in [34,35,36,39] AND direction == 'output'

rules.message: GPIO {pin} is INPUT ONLY - cannot be used for output
rules.solution: Use different pin for output signals

wire_color_standards.description: Standard wire color coding for consistent diagrams
recommendations: Always use RED for positive power
Use consistent colors within a project
Label wires when colors run out
Match component wire colors when possible (e.g., servo brown/red/orange)

component_substitutes.description: Alternative components for when originals are unavailable

substitution_types.functional_equivalent: Same function, may need wiring changes

pin_compatible.code_change: Change DHT type constant from DHT11 to DHT22

functional_equivalent.differences: I2C instead of OneWire, adds pressure
Laser ToF, I2C, more accurate, shorter range

functional_equivalent.code_change: Analog read instead of pulse timing

upgrade.differences: Much stronger (10kg), larger, needs more power
upgrade.code_change: None, but ensure adequate power supply

pin_compatible.differences: Faster (48MHz vs 16MHz), more RAM, same pinout

functional_equivalent.code_change: Pin numbers may differ for shields

pin_compatible.differences: Same chip, different board layout possible

upgrade.differences: USB native, AI acceleration, more GPIO
RISC-V core, lower power, fewer GPIO
Sensor fusion onboard, easier to use

protection_requirements.description: Required protection components for safe circuits

flyback_diode.reason: Suppresses voltage spike when coil turns off

bulk_capacitor.placement: Across 5V and GND near first LED

data_resistor.placement: In series with data line, near MCU

flyback_diode.placement: Across motor terminals, cathode to positive

pullup_resistors.placement: SDA to VCC, SCL to VCC
pullup_resistors.reason: I2C is open-drain, needs pullups to work
pullup_resistors.note: Most modules include pullups - don't double up

pullup_or_pulldown.reason: Prevents floating input when switch open

debounce_capacitor.reason: Hardware debouncing (can also do in software)

decoupling.placement: As close to IC VCC/GND as possible

quick_reference.motor: Add flyback diode + optional 0.1µF across terminals
quick_reference.5V_to_3V3: Add voltage divider (1K + 2K) or level shifter

complete_circuits.description: Fully validated circuits with every wire specified

circuit_001_blink.name: LED Blink (Hello World)
circuit_001_blink.description: Classic first circuit - blink an LED

circuit_002_ultrasonic_distance.name: Ultrasonic Distance Sensor
circuit_002_ultrasonic_distance.validation_notes: Verified. Echo returns 5V signal, safe for Arduino.

circuit_003_temp_humidity.name: Temperature & Humidity Monitor
circuit_003_temp_humidity.validation_notes: 10K pullup may be built into module. Test without first.

circuit_004_servo_control.name: Servo Motor Control
circuit_004_servo_control.power_warning: Single servo OK on USB, multiple servos need external 5V
circuit_004_servo_control.validation_notes: Works on USB for single servo. Add 100uF cap for stability.

circuit_005_i2c_lcd.name: I2C LCD Display
circuit_005_i2c_lcd.validation_notes: Address usually 0x27 or 0x3F. Run I2C scanner if display blank.

circuit_006_mpu6050_motion.name: 6-Axis Motion Sensor
circuit_006_mpu6050_motion.validation_notes: Default I2C address 0x68. Set AD0 HIGH for 0x69.

circuit_007_esp32_ultrasonic.name: ESP32 Ultrasonic (3.3V MCU)
circuit_007_esp32_ultrasonic.description: HC-SR04 with ESP32 - REQUIRES LEVEL SHIFTING
circuit_007_esp32_ultrasonic.critical_warning: ESP32 is 3.3V! HC-SR04 Echo outputs 5V! MUST use voltage divider!
circuit_007_esp32_ultrasonic.validation_notes: TESTED - voltage divider essential to prevent GPIO damage

circuit_008_ws2812b_strip.name: WS2812B LED Strip
circuit_008_ws2812b_strip.description: Addressable RGB LED strip with proper protection
protection_notes: 330Ω resistor on data line prevents reflections
Common ground between MCU and power supply ESSENTIAL
circuit_008_ws2812b_strip.validation_notes: TESTED - protection components prevent first-LED failure

circuit_009_rfid_reader.name: RFID Card Reader
circuit_009_rfid_reader.critical_warning: RC522 is 3.3V ONLY! Use Arduino 3.3V pin, NOT 5V!
circuit_009_rfid_reader.validation_notes: TESTED - 3.3V power essential, Arduino 5V GPIO works for signals

circuit_010_stepper_motor.name: Stepper Motor Control
circuit_010_stepper_motor.power_warning: Stepper draws 240mA - NEVER power from Arduino 5V pin
circuit_010_stepper_motor.validation_notes: TESTED - pin order in Stepper library is IN1,IN3,IN2,IN4 (not sequential!)

troubleshooting_trees.description: Systematic diagnostic trees for common circuit problems

diagnostic_steps.how: Check power LED on board, measure 5V/3.3V with multimeter

likely_causes.solution: Try different USB cable
Try different port or powered hub

likely_causes.cause: Short circuit drawing too much current
likely_causes.solution: Disconnect all components, test MCU alone
Try uploading blink sketch to known-good board

diagnostic_steps.how: Upload basic blink, verify LED D13 blinks

likely_causes.solution: Check Tools > Board menu
Check Tools > Port, try different ports
Burn bootloader via ISP programmer
Replace chip if socketed

diagnostic_steps.how: Verify continuity between all GND points with multimeter

likely_causes.solution: Add ground connection
Reseat wires, check breadboard contacts
Replace jumper wire

diagnostic_steps.how: Measure VCC at component with multimeter

likely_causes.solution: Check pinout diagram
Verify breadboard internal connections

likely_causes.cause: Power rail not connected to MCU
likely_causes.solution: Add wire from MCU 5V/3.3V to power rail

diagnostic_steps.check: Wiggle test - does touching wires affect behavior?
diagnostic_steps.how: Gently push on each wire connection while running

likely_causes.solution: Reseat wire, use fresh breadboard row
Clean with fine sandpaper or replace
Use different rows or new breadboard

diagnostic_steps.check: Power stability - measure VCC during operation
diagnostic_steps.how: Watch multimeter while circuit operates

likely_causes.solution: Use external power supply
Add 100nF ceramic + 100µF electrolytic near component
Power motors from separate supply, share ground

diagnostic_steps.how: Move motor/relay away from sensor, add shielding

likely_causes.solution: Add 0.1µF across motor, use shielded cables

likely_causes.cause: Long signal wires acting as antenna
likely_causes.solution: Shorten wires, use twisted pairs for signals
Separate analog and digital signals physically

sensor_reads_wrong_values.symptom: Sensor returns data but values are incorrect

diagnostic_steps.how: Check datasheet for min/max measurement range

likely_causes.solution: Move target to valid range (2-400cm for HC-SR04)

diagnostic_steps.how: Compare against known reference (ruler, thermometer)

likely_causes.solution: Calculate offset from known value, apply in code
Adjust formula constants for actual sensor

diagnostic_steps.how: Verify sensor VCC matches expected, check signal levels

likely_causes.solution: Check sensor voltage rating

likely_causes.cause: Signal level mismatch causing bit errors
likely_causes.solution: Add level shifter if needed

i2c_device_not_found.symptom: I2C scanner finds no devices or wrong address

diagnostic_steps.how: Verify A4=SDA, A5=SCL on Uno; GPIO21=SDA, GPIO22=SCL on ESP32

likely_causes.solution: Swap the two wires
Check pinout for your specific board

diagnostic_steps.how: Measure resistance from SDA to VCC, SCL to VCC (should be 1K-10K)

likely_causes.solution: Add 4.7K resistors from SDA to VCC, SCL to VCC
Some bare modules need external pull-ups

diagnostic_steps.how: Check if multiple devices share address, verify expected address

likely_causes.solution: Change address via hardware pin (AD0 on MPU6050)

likely_causes.cause: Device uses different address than expected
likely_causes.solution: Common: LCD 0x27 or 0x3F, MPU6050 0x68 or 0x69

diagnostic_steps.how: Measure VCC at device

likely_causes.solution: Use correct voltage for device
Check power connections

spi_device_not_responding.symptom: SPI device doesn't respond or returns garbage

diagnostic_steps.how: Verify MOSI/MISO/SCK/SS match MCU's hardware SPI pins

likely_causes.solution: MOSI→MOSI, MISO←MISO (same name connects)
Arduino Uno: MOSI=11, MISO=12, SCK=13, SS=10

diagnostic_steps.how: Check code pulls SS LOW before transfer, HIGH after

likely_causes.solution: digitalWrite(SS, LOW) before SPI.transfer()

likely_causes.cause: SS pin not set as OUTPUT
likely_causes.solution: Add pinMode(SS, OUTPUT) in setup()

diagnostic_steps.how: Check device datasheet for SPI mode (0,1,2,3)

likely_causes.solution: Set SPI.beginTransaction(SPISettings(1000000, MSBFIRST, SPI_MODE0))
Reduce SPI clock speed

servo_jittering.symptom: Servo vibrates, doesn't hold position, or moves erratically

diagnostic_steps.how: Measure voltage at servo while moving - should stay above 4.8V

likely_causes.solution: Use external 5V supply, share ground with MCU
Use supply rated for at least 1A per servo

diagnostic_steps.how: Check with oscilloscope if available, or try different PWM pin

likely_causes.solution: Shorten signal wire, add 0.1µF cap near servo
Servo library conflicts with other PWM - check pin assignments

diagnostic_steps.how: Disconnect servo arm, test free movement

likely_causes.solution: Adjust mechanical limits in code
Replace servo

diagnostic_steps.check: First LED dead or random colors?
diagnostic_steps.how: Observe first LED behavior compared to rest

likely_causes.solution: Add 1000µF capacitor across power, cut off damaged LED
Add 300-500Ω resistor on data line near MCU

diagnostic_steps.check: LEDs dim or wrong color at end of strip?
diagnostic_steps.how: Compare brightness/color of first vs last LEDs

likely_causes.solution: Inject power every 50-100 LEDs
Calculate: LEDs × 60mA = required current at full white

diagnostic_steps.how: Check if MCU is 3.3V logic

likely_causes.cause: 3.3V data signal too low for 5V LEDs
likely_causes.solution: Add 74HCT125 level shifter or power first LED from 3.3V
Sometimes works - try shorter data wire first

breadboard_zone_rules.description: Best practices for physical breadboard layout

internal_connections.power_rails: entire length connected vertically (some have break in middle)

best_practice: Connect MCU 5V to red rail, GND to blue rail first
Add 100µF electrolytic capacitor across rails for stability
Check if rail has center break - add jumper if needed

use_cases: Second voltage level (3.3V if top is 5V)
best_practice: Always connect grounds together between rails
Place MCU with USB port accessible at edge
Wide modules (ESP32) may need two breadboards
Keep analog sensors away from switching signals
Place noise-sensitive sensors away from motors/relays
Use separate power supply for motors
Add flyback diodes near inductive loads
Keep motor wires short and away from signal wires
Group LEDs with their current-limiting resistors
Keep LED wires short for clean appearance

wire_length.rule: Keep wires as short as practical
wire_length.reason: Reduces noise pickup and voltage drop
wire_length.exception: Power wires can be longer than signal wires

rules: Cross wires at 90° angles when necessary
Use different colors for different signal types

component_orientation.ics: Notch/dot indicating pin 1 faces same direction for all ICs
component_orientation.leds: All cathodes (flat side) facing same direction
component_orientation.electrolytics: All positive leads facing same direction

implementation: Place analog sensors on opposite side from PWM outputs
Use dedicated analog ground if very sensitive
Add 0.1µF cap near analog input pins

decoupling.rule: Add decoupling capacitors near every IC
implementation: 0.1µF ceramic as close as possible to VCC/GND pins

ground_routing.rule: Use star ground topology for sensitive circuits
implementation: Single point where all grounds meet
Separate paths for noisy loads (motors) and sensitive inputs

common_mistakes.symptom: Half of IC pins don't work
common_mistakes.solution: Place DIP ICs straddling the center gap

common_mistakes.symptom: Components on one half don't power up
common_mistakes.solution: Add jumper across power rail break point (if present)

common_mistakes.symptom: Cap gets hot, may bulge or pop
LED burns out immediately or is very dim after
common_mistakes.solution: Always use resistor - even 100Ω is better than none

common_mistakes.symptom: Device runs hot, erratic behavior, or immediate failure

common_mistakes.mistake: No common ground between power supplies
common_mistakes.solution: Always connect GND between all supplies and MCU

common_mistakes.mistake: Using cheap/old breadboard with worn contacts
common_mistakes.solution: Try different rows, replace breadboard if old

layout: Bottom rail: LED power (may need external)
Note: LED strip connects via wires, not on breadboard

contributor_guide:
### Contributor Guide

- Use consistent IDs such as `category-component_name` (e.g. `sensor-dht11`).
- Populate mandatory fields: `name`, `id`, `datasheet_url`, `pinout_image`, `operating_voltage_v`, `wiring_rules`, `tags`, `use_cases`.
- When adding application notes, include a descriptive title and a valid URL.
- Example circuits should include a description, a title and a URL to a working project or tutorial.
- Substitute parts must be classified by compatibility (drop‑in, pin‑to‑pin or functionally equivalent) and document any required adjustments such as voltage scaling or pin mapping.
- Add `compatibility_notes` summarizing voltage, current and logic‑level considerations and note if level shifters or pull‑ups are needed.
- Use `project_tags` to tag the part by typical applications (e.g. weather_station, display_module).
- When modifying stock quantity, update the appropriate entry in `documentation_categories` (purchase_orders, receipts or adjustments).
- Document all changes in the changelog with the date and a concise description of what changed.
